image_analysis.description: A photograph of a single page from a book, showing two columns of printed text. The page is slightly curved at the spine, which is visible in the center. The bottom of the image includes a document identifier.
image_analysis.layout: Two-column text layout. A header is present at the top of each column, a page number at the bottom of the left column, and a document identifier at the bottom right of the entire image.

text_extraction.full_text:
JAMES PATTERSON

FILT

good life. Parties in Vegas; weekends in the Hamptons; affairs with beautiful women that end up getting splashed all over the tabloids.

It makes sense that, once upon a time, he and Epstein would have gotten along.

"As for the girls," Meister says, "that was just business. He'd seat them strategically at client dinners. When he went to the movies, he'd take three or four girls with him. They'd take turns massaging his back, arms, and legs."

According to Meister, Epstein used to boast that he "liked to go into insane asylums because he liked to fuck crazy women."

"Who knows if it's true?" Meister adds. "But I'm telling you, he used to say it."

From time to time, Epstein's friends and acquaintances would see sides of Epstein that he'd grown much less shy about sharing.

Epstein encouraged Alan Dershowitz to invest with a prominent hedge-fund manager named Orin Kramer. Dershowitz did, and he made a lot of money at first. But in 2008, the fund Dershowitz had invested in lost a substantial amount. Afterward, according to a former associate of Epstein's, Epstein appeared in Kramer's midtown Manhattan office. There, sources say, he told Kramer: "It's very much in your interest to make Alan Dershowitz whole."

Epstein's intervention worked, and Dershowitz recovered his money.

To people who'd known Epstein back in the 1980s, this kind of behavior was out of character. But the thing about Epstein was that you never could figure him out. One minute he was charming.

The most charming man you'd threat, and bluster. Something numbers: this many parties, t connection to Victoria's Secret,

document_metadata.subject: Account of Jeffrey Epstein's behavior, relationships, and financial dealings, including interactions with Meister and Alan Dershowitz.

notes: The image is a photograph of a page from the book 'Filth' by James Patterson. The text in the right column is partially cut off at the right margin. The name 'James Truma' is likely a typo in the book for James Truman. The document identifier 'HOUSE_OVERSIGHT_010497' indicates this page was part of evidence or documentation for the House Oversight Committee.
